subject: RE: [junit] Do JUnit internals suck?!?
msgSnippet: ... Good suggestion and that would have worked for me if it was on the instance side. I would like to have a bunch of existing test classes in a hierarchy
messageBody:
Steven Taschuk wrote:
> Quoth Michael Silverstein:
> > Mr. Loritsch exactly describes the problem I ran into yesterday while
> > extending the Test Mentor tool to have its test components
> (that live in a
> > different hierarchy) appear like JUnit tests. My first
> inclination was to
> > simply have Test Mentor test components implement the
> junit.framework.Test
> > interface and then implement countTestCases() and run(TestResult). The
> > problem I ran in to is that we don't compose tests by way of methods
> > beginning with 'testxxx', as JUnit does. What would have made
> the job a lot
> > easier would have been some method in the Test interface that
> is passed a
> > test collector, such as collectTests(TestCollector), for example.
> [...]
>
> Doesn't the
> public static TestSuite suite()
> method solve this problem? Certainly it has about the semantics
> you want -- "give me the set of tests you consist of".

Good suggestion and that would have worked for me if it was on the instance
side. I would like to have a bunch of existing test classes in a hierarchy
generically inherit the "give me the set of tests you consist of" behavior.
If I did it on the static side, I would require each existing and future
class in the hierarchy to implement a static suite() method, which would be
a big imposition on our existing customers, just on the off chance that they
might want to run their tests under JUnit.
